title.rendered: Explore Job Roles: Judicial Law Clerks

content.rendered:
What is a Judicial Law Clerk?

Judicial Law Clerks assist judges with tasks like preparing legal documents and researching information related to cases.

Where does a Judicial Law Clerk work?

  • State judges
  • Federal judges

How much does a Judicial Law Clerk make?

Based on real new grad salaries reported through Handshake, the median annual salary for a Judicial Law Clerk is $57,000.

What majors are typically interested in becoming Judicial Law Clerks?

One’s major doesn’t necessarily determine their career, but these are some common majors of those who end up pursuing this career path.

  • Political science majors
  • Philosophy majors
  • English majors
Search Judicial Law Clerk jobs

Judicial Law Clerk skills and competencies:

On top of a relevant degree and formal training, here are some professional skills that can help aspiring Judicial Law Clerks succeed in their work:

  • High attention to detail
  • Knowledge of legal terminology

What are some common questions about Judicial Law Clerks?

Q: How do I prepare for a Judicial Law Clerk interview?

A: Before your interview, make sure to go over your resume and cover letter–know your experiences well and play to your strengths. It’s also important to research the judge you’re trying to clerk for and familiarize yourself with the person who is interviewing you ahead of time.

excerpt.rendered: Learn about the average salary, relevant studies, related questions, and common path after college to becoming a Judicial Law Clerk.
